alt_statements.statement: I think campus administrators need to protect students’ right to protest and speak out, but they also have to keep everyone safe and stop any hate or threats, whether against Jewish students, Muslim students, or anyone else. Coming from a country that’s seen a lot of struggle, I believe young people should be allowed to raise their voices for justice, but the rules should be clear and enforced fairly so campuses don’t turn into places of fear or violence.

I think the people in charge at colleges should make sure everyone is safe and not let anyone hurt or bully other people, even if they disagree about Israel and Gaza. They should remind students to be kind and listen to each other, because it’s important to care about people’s feelings and remember that God wants us to love our neighbors.

As someone who believes in social justice and has seen people at their most vulnerable during my years in nursing, I think university administrators must protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel and Gaza, while enforcing clear, consistent rules against harassment, threats, and discrimination of any kind. They should create structured spaces for dialogue, provide support for students who feel unsafe or targeted, and resist pressure—whether from politicians or donors—to silence peaceful political expression.

As a conservative Catholic and a mom who wants her kids to grow up in a safe and respectful environment, I think university administrators should allow peaceful demonstrations about Israel and Gaza, but draw a hard line at any kind of harassment, vandalism, or calls for violence. Free speech is important, but so is making sure Jewish and Muslim students, and everyone else, feel physically safe and not targeted because of who they are.

As a retired teacher and a conservative, I believe university administrators have a duty to uphold free speech while also enforcing clear rules that prevent violence, harassment, and disruption of classes. Peaceful demonstrations about Israel and Gaza should be allowed, but the moment they intimidate Jewish or Muslim students, block campus operations, or turn into encampments that defy reasonable policies, administrators need to step in firmly and consistently.

I think campus administrators should protect students’ right to protest peacefully about Israel and Gaza, but also step in quickly if things turn hateful or threatening so everyone still feels safe. They should encourage open discussions where people can actually listen to each other instead of just yelling, maybe with moderated forums or teach-ins that share facts and multiple perspectives. As someone who’s still figuring out what I believe, I’d want a campus environment that lets students ask hard questions and care about injustice, but in a way that respects the dignity and safety of everyone involved.

As someone who has spent her life in the arts, I believe university administrators should protect peaceful protest as a vital form of expression while firmly preventing harassment, violence, and discrimination against any group—Jewish, Muslim, Palestinian, Israeli, or otherwise. They should create structured forums for dialogue, teach historical context, and listen closely to students on all sides, rather than rushing to criminalize or silence them. Balancing safety with free speech is hard, but it’s precisely in painful, polarizing moments like Israel/Gaza that universities must model empathy, critical thinking, and respect for human dignity.

As someone who cares deeply about both justice and community, I believe university administrators must protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel/Gaza while enforcing clear, consistent rules against harassment, threats, and disruption of learning. Rather than resorting quickly to police or blanket restrictions, they should facilitate dialogue, provide support for those who feel unsafe, and ensure that Palestinian, Israeli, Jewish, Muslim, and other affected students are all treated with equal dignity and concern.

University administrators need to protect students’ right to protest and speak out on Israel/Gaza, but they also have to draw a hard line at harassment, doxxing, or anything that makes people feel physically unsafe. Administrators should set clear rules, enforce them consistently, and not bend to the loudest group, but instead uphold order, respect, and responsibility for everyone on campus.

As someone who cares deeply about justice and human dignity, I think university administrators should protect students’ rights to peaceful protest on Israel/Gaza while setting firm, consistent boundaries against harassment, hate speech, and disruption of learning. As a retired professor, I believe university administrators have a duty to protect robust free expression and peaceful protest, including on contentious issues like Israel and Gaza, while drawing a clear, consistently enforced line against harassment, incitement, and discrimination of any kind. I think campus administrators need to protect free speech like it’s the frame of the whole vehicle, but also step in when things cross the line into threats, harassment, or blocking other students from getting to class. University administrators need to enforce clear, even‑handed rules that protect free speech but do not allow intimidation, harassment, or disruption of classes and campus operations. Campus administrators should protect the broadest possible space for peaceful expression on all sides while drawing a bright, non-negotiable line at threats, harassment, and any attempt to shut others down.
